resource.chars: Through the name of New Accident
They would call the lady.
And when the common folk would speak
Of what happened,
The lady would be able to obtain
A great reputation and another name,
That the lower classes would give herâ€”
This would be Fortune.
Because I am terrifying,
They call me Frightening,
And truly this is reasonable,
For I am always
Worthy of great fear!
I am strong and cruel, truly,
And whatever I decide to torment
Cannot heal or lift itself up
Until I decide to take it under my care.
And I am tall beyond all measure,
Since I can reach the sky,
And hold everything in my hand,
And my feet reach the earth.
I am a lady of peace and war.
There is no one who hears someone speak of me
Who does not fear me strongly,
For through me everything must end,
Everything that happens in this world.
I grant poverty and wealth,
Strength and beauty, joy and sadness...
I am a lady, I am a queen,
To some I am cruel, to others benign,
And I make everyone quickly a neighbor
Of that ragged pilgrim
Who destroys everything, namely Death.
For without respite she bites here and there
Such that no man in good fortune
Should sleep soundly,
Rather he should always be anxious
That he not behave so as to displease
God, my father, who gives everything,
And who repays all things bad and good,
Who holds Pride in such hatred,
Both her and her relatives,
That he cannot suffer her for a long time
Without crushing her horribly.
Nebuchadnezzar, the king,
I will show you as an example,
For he was once so drunk
Off of the great honors I gave him
That he took confidence in his position,
And forgot his Creator,
And made everyone, through a very foolish action,
Worship his image.
He did not remember my father,
And for this reason he had to face the consequences,
For I quickly threw him
Into such horrible poverty
That he had to go graze with the animals!
He had to live naked for seven years.
And pride once made the angels
Fall out of paradise.
And I can prove truly through
A great abundance of other examples,
Which are long and lengthy to tell,
That no man should let Pride grew inside him
Or feel resentment,
Because he has great fortune
In some things in this mortal life,
According to the spin of my wheel.
For all of this comes from my small wheels,
Which are always renewing things,
And in which everyone can contemplate himself
In order to behave wisely.
But it is true that the wise man
Has sovereignty over the stars;
And this is to say that knowledge
Surpasses the influence of planets,
Creating a certain disposition
On the corporeal complexion.
For there is no one, I tell you this truly,
Who, if he is inclined towards a vice,
Through his natural complexion,
According to the constellation
Through which he might have that sin,
And through which he is more inclined to sin,
Who cannot renounce it and refrain,
If he lives according to and remains in reason.
In the same way, works of charity
And prayers of humility
When a man or a woman pronounces them
In good faith, in front of his Father,
Temper the occurrences
That would otherwise be too difficult.
I will prove it to you through the example of the city of Nineveh,
A city about which one finds written
That my father decided to strike it
And make it quickly perish
Because of the great sins
That were present there.
And Jonah prophesied to them,
But the people quickly began to
Beg for mercy and cry,
To wear hairshirts and to adore God,
To fast, both them and their animals,
And to cover their heads in ash.
And God, who is full of mercy,
When he saw their humility,
Revoked, in his goodness,
The evil that he had planned to do.
And also through the King Ezekiel
To whom God revealed through Isaiah,
That he would die quickly
And who began then to cry
Tenderly and to adore God,
And God quickly, without hesitating,
Extended the King Ezekiel's life
By fifteen years.
For this reason, I tell you, since I know this,
That hope and prayer are not
Placed in God in vain.
For whoever wishes to do this in the correct way,
They [the prayers] cannot lose effectiveness
To obtain the full grace of God.
And know truly
That a man who lives wisely
Does not fall into as many perils
As people with a foolish spirit.
Nevertheless, no one can be so wise,
Whether he is a philosopher or a master,
That he can avoid all accidents
Which I have made occur through my wheels,
For often many good and wise men
Are subjected to misfortune and suffering
Without fault or merit.
The proof is sufficiently clear,
And, if I must demonstrate it further,
I well recall Boethius,
Who was a man of good life
And a master of philosophy.
He was so loyal, wise and honest
And the emperors of Rome
Believed him to be wise among the wise
And loved him and honored him.
But through the treacherous Envy
Who multiplies every day,
Boethius was betrayed unfairly,
So that he fell from his position,
And my wheel brought him down
So that he was very disconsolate.
But the beautiful Philosophy
Whom he loved, and whom he never abandoned,
Comforted him sweetly
And showed him very clearly
What I am and what I know how to do,
And why I am both sweet and bitter.
And she told him that, on account of my anger,
No wise man should be astonished.
